top_comments_top.body:
As a reminder, this subreddit [is for civil discussion.](/r/politics/wiki/index#wiki_be_civil)

In general, be courteous to others. Debate/discuss/argue the merits of ideas, don't attack people. Personal insults, shill or troll accusations, hate speech, any suggestion or support of harm, violence, or death, and other rule violations can result in a permanent ban. 

If you see comments in violation of our rules, please report them.

 For those who have questions regarding any media outlets being posted on this subreddit, please click [here](https://www.reddit.com/r/politics/wiki/approveddomainslist) to review our details as to our approved domains list and outlet criteria.

***


*I am a bot, and this action was performed automatically. Please [contact the moderators of this subreddit](/message/compose/?to=/r/politics) if you have any questions or concerns.*

I'm of two minds about this story.  I understand that these people are suffering financially due to disruptive technology.  The city may have played a role in this situation, however, the medallion owners are the ones that took this risk to achieve financial security.  Sometimes these things don't work out.   I know it isn't a great option, but bankruptcy laws are in place for this reason.
I have definitely used taxis while in NYC.  You can just flag them down from the side of the road.  Honestly, more convenient than Uber when needed quickly.  And often, less expensive too.

I don't know anything about taxi medallions other than what's in the article, but they sound a lot like liquor licenses in my state. On one hand, they cost a goddamned fortune. On the other, they're basically a license to print money.
Do people still use taxis? I mean I guess if you need to get to the airport in less than 10 minutes and don't care about your safety or hygine it is the fastest way.
